headline.main: Barbie Is More Than Just a Glamour Girl

results.snippet: To the Editor:    Well-meaning but misinformed scholars who blame the negative self-images of little girls on the Barbie doll's figure (Arts pages, Nov. 29) should bear in mind two important points.
results.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Well-meaning but misinformed scholars who blame the negative self-images of little girls on the Barbie doll's figure (Arts pages, Nov. 29) should bear in mind two important points.

results.abstract: Space shuttle Columbia astronaut tests robotic camera that beams back to earth television views of shuttle (S)
results.snippet: An astronaut walking in space tossed out a robotic camera today and watched as it soared 40 feet above the space shuttle Columbia and beamed back to earth television views of the shuttle from nose to tail. The camera, a white sphere  about the size...
results.lead_paragraph: An astronaut walking in space tossed out a robotic camera today and watched as it soared 40 feet above the space shuttle Columbia and beamed back to earth television views of the shuttle from nose to tail. The camera, a white sphere about the size of a beach ball, flitted above and about the shuttle's open cargo bay for more than an hour in its first test in space. As soon as the astronaut, Capt. Winston E. Scott of the Navy, retrieved the camera, the shuttle pilot, Maj. Steven W. Lindsey of the Air Force, announced ''a home run.''

results.abstract: R W Apple profile of Detroit; recalls childhood memories of city before rivers of asphalt that Detroit built to handle its own cars carried white population away to suburbs, leaving rotting core; relates latest comeback attempt, as General Motors moves into Renaissance Center, Lions return to new stadium near new Tigers ballpask, and licenses are granted for three casinos; reports cultural riches also abound, from Detroit Symphony to Arts Institute and new Museum of African-American History; photos; map (M)

headline.main: A City Built on Four Wheels and a Full Tank

results.snippet: I remember Detroit during its days of glory in the late 1940's, when the assembly lines were churning out the cars the country had gone without all during the war. It was a proud, self-confident city.    My father took me there to watch the Tigers'...
results.lead_paragraph: I remember Detroit during its days of glory in the late 1940's, when the assembly lines were churning out the cars the country had gone without all during the war. It was a proud, self-confident city. My father took me there to watch the Tigers' great lefthander, Hal Newhouser. We would stay at the Statler or the Book-Cadillac, a pair of swell big-city hotels, shop for my mother at Hudson's, one of the nation's premier department stores, and eat dinner at Lester Gruber's London Chop House, a clublike restaurant that served better food and wine than any club I know of.

results.abstract: Astronauts aboard space shuttle Columbia wrap up experiments and brace for barrage of questions back home about runaway science satellite; National Aeronautics and Space Administration is forming investigation team to look into botched satellite solar mission and plans to impound spacecraft after shuttle lands on Dec 5 (S)

headline.main: Shuttle Sets Return From Space Mission That Had a Failure

results.snippet: After more than two weeks aloft, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia wrapped up experiments today and braced for a barrage of questions back home about a runaway science satellite.    The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is...
results.lead_paragraph: After more than two weeks aloft, the astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia wrapped up experiments today and braced for a barrage of questions back home about a runaway science satellite. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is forming an investigation team to look into the botched satellite solar mission and plans to impound the spacecraft after the shuttle lands on Friday, weather permitting.

results.abstract: Astronauts on space shuttle Columbia return to a lukewarm welcome at Cape Canaveral, Fla, and inquiry into their bungled release of a Spartan satellite; photo (M)

headline.main: Shuttle Lands, And Inquiry Is Scheduled On Mission

results.snippet: Their mission over but hardly accomplished, the astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia returned today to a lukewarm welcome and an inquiry into their bungled release of a satellite.    The shuttle's commander, Kevin Kregel, tried to make the best...
results.lead_paragraph: Their mission over but hardly accomplished, the astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia returned today to a lukewarm welcome and an inquiry into their bungled release of a satellite. The shuttle's commander, Kevin Kregel, tried to make the best of it.

results.abstract: Committee of National Research Council warns NASA to pay more attention to risks of space debris and meteoroids and move ahead with more steps to shield space shuttles' critical systems; Nicholas L Johnson, NASA's orbiting debris program manager, says agency has already started taking steps recommended by committee to reduce the risk from space junk and meteoroids (M)

headline.main: NASA Is Warned About Risks of Meteoroids and Space Debris

results.snippet: NASA should pay more attention to the risks of space debris and meteoroids  and move ahead with more steps to shield the space shuttles' critical systems, a National Research Council committee said today.    The space agency has not done a systematic...
results.lead_paragraph: NASA should pay more attention to the risks of space debris and meteoroids and move ahead with more steps to shield the space shuttles' critical systems, a National Research Council committee said today. The space agency has not done a systematic assessment of how to keep its four shuttles flying if essential systems are hit by space junk or meteoroids and should find a better way to calculate the risks of such hits, said the expert panel.

results.abstract: James Gleick column says Lost in Space, a 1960's TV program, which was set in 1997, reveals the difficulty of predicting technological developments; creators of show expected that man would be much further along on space travel but would still use flashbulbs in cameras and refrigerator-size computers; cartoon (M)

headline.main: Fast Forward; Days of Future Past

results.snippet: The opening titles are about to roll, the spaceship is about to take off for planets unknown, mission control is teeming with people and the date appears on the screen in bold type. It is a year far, far in the future: 1997.    ''This is the...
results.lead_paragraph: The opening titles are about to roll, the spaceship is about to take off for planets unknown, mission control is teeming with people and the date appears on the screen in bold type. It is a year far, far in the future: 1997. ''This is the beginning,'' intones the narrator. ''This is the day. You are watching the unfolding of one of history's great adventures.'' It's the unfolding, anyway, of the first episode of the television series ''Lost in Space,'' as it ran on CBS in 1965, in the salad days of the American space program. The Sci-Fi Channel has been rerunning it, in all its splendor.
